headline: George W. Bush maxes out political donations to Trump impeachment supporters Liz Cheney and Lisa Murkowski
author: Bryan Metzger
sentences: Former President George W. Bush gave the maximum allowed political contributions to Wyoming Rep. Liz Cheney and Alaska Sen. Lisa Murkowski, two Republicans who supported impeaching former President Donald Trump over the January 6 Capitol riot.

Given her relatively moderate voting record, Murkowski has long been vulnerable to primary challenges, and she waged a successful write-in campaign in 2010 after losing that year's Republican primary.
Cheney was one of 10 House Republicans who voted to impeach Trump over inciting an insurrection on January 6, while Murkowski was one of seven Republican senators who voted to convict him.
Cheney, the daughter of Bush's own vice president, Dick Cheney, and an outspoken Trump critic, now serves as the lead Republican on the House Select Committee investigating January 6.

"But in their disdain for pluralism, in their disregard for human life, in their determination to defile national symbols, they are children of the same foul spirit.

Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images; Jim Watson/AFP via Getty Images
George W. Bush maxed out his political donations by giving to campaigns for Cheney and Murkowski.
In addition to these personal contributions, Bush held a fundraiser for Cheney in Dallas last fall, and he has repeatedly condemned the attacks on January 6.
"There is little cultural overlap between violent extremists abroad and violent extremists at home," Bush said during a speech in Shanksville, Pennsylvania.
New disclosures filed with the Federal Election Commission said Bush gave Cheney $5,800 on October 28 for both the general and primary elections.
Cheney has outraised Hageman by more than four to one  $2 million for Cheney versus $440,00 for Hageman  FEC disclosures showed.
She's set to face off against Harriet Hageman, a former RNC official who has been endorsed by Trump, in an August primary.
On the 20th anniversary of the 9/11 terror attacks, Bush compared domestic right-wing extremists to the 9/11 perpetrators.
In Alaska, Murkowski faces Kelly Tshibaka, a former commissioner of the Alaska Department of Administration.
From left: Rep. Liz Cheney of Wyoming, former President George W. Bush, and Sen. Lisa Murkowski of Alaska.
Eric Greitens  who's called for Sen. Mitch McConnell to lose his place atop the Senate Republican Caucus.
Tshibaka is one of two GOP senate candidates  the other being the scandal-plagued former Missouri Gov.
FEC records indicated that Bush didn't make any other political contributions in 2021 before October.
Both supported impeaching Trump over the insurrection and now face Trump-backed primary challengers.
Bush has also held a fundraiser for Cheney and condemned the January 6 attack on the Capitol.
